pullRequest.body:
The density of a finite set in an ambient group is a quantity of great interest in combinatorics.
This PR defines `Finset.dens s` for `s : Finset α` as the size of `s` divided by the size of `α`, with value in any semifield.
The API lemmas are copied from `Finset.card` (but not all `Finset.card` lemmas are sensible `Finset.dens` lemmas).

From LeanAPAP


---

nodes.body: See also `commProb` which you may want to port to the new definition. Also, do you plan to link it to the measure theory probability w.r.t. the uniform distribution?

> See also `commProb` which you may want to port to the new definition.

Nice observation! Will do so in a later PR.

> do you plan to link it to the measure theory probability w.r.t. the uniform distribution?

Maybe in a distant future but right now I don't need it.

bors merge
@eric-wieser, any suggestion to avoid running `proveFinsetNonempty` twice?
I'd argue that this should live in `NNRat` not `Semifield 𝕜`, for the same reason that `card` lives in `Nat` not `Semiring R`.
... which maybe explains why you want `NNRat.cast`! Is `Rat` suitable enough in the meantime?

Actually, the reason I want `NNRat.cast` is not this but the closely-related `Finset.expect` that still lives [in LeanAPAP](https://github.com/YaelDillies/LeanAPAP/blob/master/LeanAPAP/Prereqs/Expect/Basic.lean).

Having this be `NNRat`/`Rat`-valued will be very annoying since `dens` is meant to be an analytic object. Most uses of it will be in `Real`.

The disadvantage of having `dens` be `𝕜`-valued is that if one person writes a theorem about `dens[ℚ] s`, and another person wants to apply that theorem to deduce something about `dens[ℝ] s`, it's quite annoying to prove that those two things are actually equal. You would have to unfold the definition at a minimum. So you end up forcing everyone to use the same field if they want their results to be compatible.

On the other hand, suppose that you were to change the function `dens` to be `ℚ`-valued. It would still be possible to type `(dens s : ℝ)`. It would probably even still be possible to define the notation `dens[𝕜] s` to mean `(dens s : 𝕜)`, if `𝕜` has a coercion from `ℚ`. So you could still state and prove all of the same theorems that you prove, as long as `𝕜` has a coercion from `ℚ`. (For some theorems you would also have to assume that `𝕜` is a `ℚ`-algebra, but I think this assumption is very reasonable.)

If you were to do this, then `dens[ℝ] s = ((dens s : ℚ) : ℝ)` would be true by definition. Also, `dens[ℚ] s = dens s` would be true by definition, too, so you wouldn't even have to make separate theorems for `dens` (by itself) and `dens[𝕜]`.

Your concerns only apply to the case where we try to talk about the density valued across several types. I conjecture this barely ever happens as all that matters are the formulas for the density of a finset constructed in a given way.

Instead I am trying to optimise for those rewritings. Eg my API can rewrite `(s ∪ t).dens + (s ∩ t).dens = s.dens + t.dens` where everything is real-valued in one lemma. In contrast, your suggested API will painfully get there by doing
```
rw [← Nat.cast_add, dens_union_add_dens_inter, Nat.cast_add]
```
(assuming the rewrites by `Nat.cast` are unambiguous!)

No, you wouldn't have to do that. With my suggestion, you would still have a theorem called `dens_union_add_dens_inter` that states that `dens[𝕜] (s ∪ t) + dens[𝕜] (s ∩ t) = dens[𝕜] s + dens[𝕜] t`, and you could rewrite using that theorem in one step. It's just that `dens[𝕜] s` would mean `(dens s : 𝕜) = ((s.card / Fintype.card α : ℚ) : 𝕜)` rather than meaning `(s.card : 𝕜) / (Fintype.card α : 𝕜)` like it currently does.

Suppose you were to prove that if `s : Fin n` satisfies `dens[ℝ] s > exp(-c * (log n) ^ (1/9)))`, then `s` has a three-term arithmetic progression.

And then suppose that someone else wants to use your theorem on a set `s`. However, they only know `dens[ℚ] s > 1 / 100` because they did all their calculations with `dens[ℚ]`. Of course, this hypothetical person should be able to use your theorem, because `dens[ℚ] s` is equal to `dens[ℝ] s`. But currently, it's really hard for them to use it, because it's not obvious that they're equal.

(If you would say "Well, you should've used `dens[ℝ]` in all your calculations, because that's the standard", then that essentially means that `dens[ℝ]` is the only supported use case. In this case, `dens` should just be valued in `ℝ`, and you wouldn't even have to write the `[ℝ]`. Actually, I think this wouldn't be so bad.)

I don't really think that's a strong argument. In your example, translation happens at exactly one point, so there's little overhead (and in contrast you aren't mentioning the countless uses of `NNRat.cast_add` that having `Finset.density` be `NNRat`-valued involves).

If you want an argument that I actually believe, here it is: `Finset.card` is `Nat`-valued, which in particular means it doesn't rely on the algebraic hierarchy.
I think you do not understand what I am saying. You would not need to use `NNRat.cast_add` even a single time if the API is set up correctly.

You're right. I had missed your point about just changing the definition.

If I understand you correctly, you now need two copies of each lemma:
* one for general semifields, stated with `NNRat.cast`
* one for `NNRat`, stated without `NNRat.cast`

What you seem to be missing is that the second class of lemmas can't be substituted by the first class of lemmas in rewrites. That's because `NNRat.cast : NNRat -> NNRat` is not syntactically the same as `id`.
I have done the change.
I think this ℕ is a mistake.

```suggestion
lemma dens_eq_card_div_card (s : Finset α) : dens[𝕜] s = s.card / Fintype.card α := rfl
```

```suggestion
    (p : α → Prop) [DecidablePred p] :
```
That's less syntactically general.
Good point
I thought about this a little more. Doesn't removing an extra unnecessary assumption make your theorem more general, not less general?

No, not here. Inspect your version vs my version in the infoview to make up your mind.

Hint: Removing the assumption is basically equivalent to saying "`∀ a, a + a = a + a` is more general than `∀ a b, a = b → a + b = b + a` because it doesn't have the `b` assumption". This is true mathematically (although note that saying "`b` assumption" is mathematically dodgy), but in practice it makes your theorem less applicable because when you want to rewrite some `a + b` found in nature you need Lean to be able to *unify* `a` and `b` syntactically, instead of being able to provide the proof yourself.
I see.

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
    tsub_le_iff_right.mpr dens_le_dens_sdiff_add_dens
```

```suggestion
lemma dens_sdiff_add_dens_eq_dens (h : s ⊆ t) : dens[𝕜] (t \ s) + dens s = dens t := by
```

The name of this lemma is also a little awkward, because it could equally well describe the next lemma `dens[𝕜] (s \ t) + dens t = (s ∪ t).dens`. Maybe `dens_sdiff_add_dens_of_subset` would be better.
This matches `card` lemmas, so if you want that name to change you will first need to rename the corresponding `card` lemma

```suggestion
lemma dens_le_dens_sdiff_add_dens : dens[𝕜] s ≤ dens (s \ t) + dens t :=
  dens_sdiff_add_dens (s := s) (t := t) (𝕜 := 𝕜) ▸ dens_le_dens (subset_union_left s t)
```

Maybe some of the arguments of `dens_sdiff_add_dens` should be explicit to make this even cleaner.
Here I could make some arguments to `dens_sdiff_add_dens` explicit because `card_sdiff_add_card` was only used in rewriting.

```suggestion
lemma dens_sdiff (h : s ⊆ t) : dens[𝕜] (t \ s) = dens t - dens s :=
  (tsub_eq_of_eq_add (dens_sdiff_add_dens_eq_dens h).symm).symm
```
This is surely the docstring for `card`?
Please regenerate this in a separate PR
I guess it can work for prop typeclasses, but the `IsCancelAdd ℚ≥0` argument looks pretty suspicious to me
Whoops, that's a remnant from the previous approach
